Award.AwardTitle: Dealloying Under Conditions of Significant Solid-State Mass Transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This research program examines the kinetics of dealloying and morphology evolution in alloy systems for which the solid-state mass transport processes of lattice and grain-boundary diffusion are significant at ambient temperature. The major control parameters in the work will be the alloy composition, grain size of the polycrystalline hosts, particle size in the particulate hosts and temperature. The electrochemical parameters to be varied include dissolution under conditions of fixed voltage (chronoamperometry) and fixed current (chronopotentiometry). This will allow for the separate determination of the dependence of morphology on the applied electrochemical potential and dealloying rate. In order to examine these issues a combined experimental and computational approach is used. The alloy systems under study are Li-Sn, Li-Pb and Li-Cd. These host metals and similar ones are currently being considered as anode reservoirs in future lithium-ion batteries and have been chosen for study since they represent variations in the host crystal structures, tetragonal, face-centered cubic and hexagonal close-packed, respectively, and have a rich history with abundant thermodynamic and kinetic data available. Electrochemical methods are used to produce the alloys, measure dealloying rates and determine associated solid-state mass transport rates. Dealloying morphologies are examined using focused ion-beam machining and scanning electron microscopy. Kinetic Monte Carlo simulations are used to model morphology evolution in dealloying as a function of the electrochemical potential and dealloying rate.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This research examines morphology evolution during dealloying of low melting point lithium alloys. Such alloys are currently being considered for use in advanced lithium-ion batteries in which the dealloying process corresponds to that occurring during discharge of these battery systems. The findings likely to emerge from this research will significantly impact research in energy storage and particularly the development of new materials for future batteries. As this country considers its energy options, it will need people with combined expertise in electrochemistry and materials science to address current and future energy technologies. The scope of research in this program will afford undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity for fundamental training in an integrated materials electrochemistry laboratory environment. More generally in the area of education and training, the PI will be developing a new undergraduate course in the "materials science of electrochemical energy storage and production," and the course together with all materials will be available for colleagues to use via the worldwide web.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined nanometer scale microstructural changes that occur during de-lithiation (also called dealloying) of low melting point lithium-tin and lithium-lead alloys. Such alloys are currently being considered for use in advanced lithium-ion batteries in which the dealloying process corresponds to that occurring during discharge of these battery systems. Electrochemical methods were used to characterize the de-lithiation discharge process and electron microscopy was used to connect the microstructure changes in the alloy to the rate of de-lithiation.

 Depending on the amount of lithium in the alloy and the rate of discharge, we observed three different fundamental types of morphology that evolved upon dealloying. As shown in Figure 1A, at high discharge rates, we observed porous bi-continuous structures with pore sizes ranging from about 100-1000 nanometers. At intermediate discharge rates we observed dendritic void structures (Figure 1B) and at low discharge rates we observed numerous isolated voids (Figure 1C). The structures that evolved at intermediate and low discharge rates were controlled by solid-state diffusional transport occurring during de-lithiation. The porous bi-continuous structures evolved because the rate of discharge greatly exceeded the diffusional transport within the alloy. These results were published in 2 manuscripts published in the Journal of the Electrochemical Society [1,2] and a third manuscript is currently in production [3].

 The findings that emerged from this research will significantly impact research in energy storage and particularly the development of new materials for future lithium-ion batteries. For example, it may be possible to take advantage of the nanoscale morphologies in the design of new anode reservoir architectures that simultaneously serve as current collectors and lithium reservoirs, which would serve to increase the energy density of future lithium ion batteries.

 In the area of education and training, a new undergraduate course was developed called “Materials Science of Electrochemical Energy Storage and Conversion” and the principal investigator is currently in the process of posting these materials at a website on the worldwide web. In the course of performing this research one student earned a PhD in Materials Science and Engineering.

 [1] K. Geng, K. Sieradzki, Dealloying at High Homologous Temperature: Morphology Diagrams, Journal of the Electrochemical Society, 164, pp. C330-C337 (2017).

[2] Q, Chen, K. Geng, K. Sieradzki, Prospects for Dendrite-Free Cycling of Li Metal Batteries, Journal of the Electrochemical Society, 162, pp. A2004-A2007 (2015).

[2]. K. Geng, M. Liu, Y. Xie, K. Sieradzki, De-lithiation of Li-Lb Alloys: Current Oscillations, in preparation.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2018
Modified by: Karl Sieradzki

Image
  • Morphology during dealloying of lithium-tin and lithium-lead alloys. (A) Bi-continuous structure at 2 length scales. The white arrow points to 400 nanometer and the red arrow points to a1 micron length scale structure (B) dendritic void structures indicated by white arrows (C) isolated voids.
    Karl Sieradzki
    Public Domain
    Karl Sieradzki

Such alloys are currently being considered for use in advanced lithium-ion batteries in which the dealloying process corresponds to that occurring during discharge of these battery systems. The porous bi-continuous structures evolved because the rate of discharge greatly exceeded the diffusional transport within the alloy.
